articles.title: AUGUST 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines an event schedule for August and early September 1987, primarily for an astronomical association. It features general meetings, board meetings, workshops on astrophotography, observational astronomy classes, and multiple field expeditions for stargazing and a Perseid Meteor Shower viewing. Key events include a workshop on amateur astrophotography and star parties at Fremont Peak State Park and Yosemite.
keywords: Astronomical Association of Northern California CHAMP

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW BY JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article emphasizes the urgency for members to renew their membership or bulletin subscription to continue receiving the monthly newsletter, 'Ephemeris'. Non-renewed members will cease receiving the newsletter after the current month, with a renewal form provided for convenience. Membership #24 includes the 'Ephemeris', 'Sky and Telescope' magazine, and Sky Publishing discounts, while an 'Ephemeris'-only subscription is available for $10.

articles.title: YOSEMITE TRIP
articles.summary: The article details the SJAA's annual star party weekend at Yosemite's Glacier Point on August 21st and 22nd, noting that the group campsite is at capacity and advising late registrants to secure first-come, first-served spots at Bridalveil Creek. It emphasizes the importance of the public stargazing program, urging members to prepare for telescope observations and public interaction to ensure future invitations. Members who registered but cannot attend are asked to notify the organizer.

articles.title: NEW COMPUTER
articles.summary: The SJAA has brought a new computer online, which will significantly upgrade the production of the Ephemeris newsletter. The editor plans to implement new personal publishing software for improved design and format, and future editions will benefit from higher resolution printing via a laser printer, with potential for digital photograph integration using a scanner. Until these upgrades are fully realized, the Ephemeris will continue to be printed with the ThinkJet.

articles.title: ANSWERING MACHINE NEEDED
articles.summary: The SJAA is seeking a donation of a telephone answering machine to establish an information service. This service will provide details on membership, upcoming events, and General Meeting locations. Interested donors are requested to contact the Officers and Board members listed in the Ephemeris.

articles.title: URANOMETRIA 2000.0 VOLUME 1
articles.summary: The SJAA is offering the new "Uranometria 2000.0 Volume 1" star atlas, featuring 330,000 stars and 10,300 deep-sky objects, to its members. Priced at an estimated $38.95, it's considered an excellent bargain, with a potential club discount from Sky Publishing. Interested individuals should contact Treasurer Jack Peterson to be added to the purchase list for late-month shipment.

articles.title: POOR PROSPECTS FOR PERSEIDS
articles.summary: This year's Perseid meteor shower on August 12/13 faces poor observing prospects due to a bright, waxing gibbous Moon, which will significantly interfere with visibility, especially during the predicted peak in the early morning hours. Despite this, it's suggested as a pleasant midweek backyard astronomy activity, with observers under dark skies potentially seeing 15-20 meteors per hour.

articles.title: AANC CONFERENCE
articles.summary: The Astronomical Association of Northern California (AANC) is holding its annual conference on September 19-20 at the Lawrence Hall of Science in Berkeley. The event will feature talks on astronomy, equipment, and astrophotography. A pre-conference star party is also scheduled for August 22 at Fremont Peak.

articles.title: SLIDE AND EQUIPMENT NIGHT
articles.summary: An upcoming 'Slide and Equipment Night' is scheduled for September 5th, featuring equipment demonstrations, slides from the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference, and astrophotography by club members. The club editor will also be present, showcasing a new 8-inch f/16 brass refractor on a Tinsly/Mathis/Wedlock mount.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for a used Celestron C-90 Astro-Scope, priced at $300. The telescope comes with several accessories, including eyepieces, a diagonal, a barlow lens, a simple fork mount with a motor drive, and a wooden carrying case. Although several years old, the scope has been used for less than 20 hours, indicating its good condition.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides updates on comets, noting that Comet Encke is briefly visible for Northern Hemisphere observers. It details the recent recovery of Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p) by A. Gilmore and P. M. Kilmartin, predicting a favorable appearance that could reach magnitude 7 by year-end due to its close approach to the sun and opposition.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides detailed ephemerides for Comet Sorrells (1986n) and Periodic Comet Klemola (1982i) for dates spanning late July to early September. It includes their right ascension, declination, elongation, and magnitude, along with observational notes on their visibility, movement relative to Earth and the Sun, and overall viewing prospects. Comet Sorrells is depicted as dimming and leaving, while Comet Klemola is noted as a challenging object to locate.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p)
articles.summary: This document provides an observational guide for Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p), detailing its predicted positions, magnitudes, and distances from July to September. It describes the comet's early morning visibility, its initial southern trajectory, and its eventual turn north in mid-October, encouraging observers to track its development.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: The article explains the process of computing comet orbits, starting with preliminary orbits based on initial astrometric positions from professional observatories. It highlights the growing difficulty for professional observatories to provide follow-up astrometric data due to other commitments. The piece emphasizes the critical need for amateur astronomers to contribute precise positional measurements to help refine comet orbits, noting that international amateurs have been doing this for years while American amateurs are lagging.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article, authored by Don Machholz and Rich Page, provides an overview of a specific astronomical observing site located on Rodeo Gulch Rd. near Soquel. It highlights the site's suitability for comet searching due to its wind protection and minimal traffic, along with detailed driving directions to reach it.

articles.title: Mountain View Rd.
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions and a comprehensive review of a stargazing site located off Mountain View Rd. and Rodeo Gulch Rd. It describes optimal telescope setup locations, horizon views, light pollution sources (Santa Cruz to the SSW), and local weather effects on transparency. The site, at approximately 600 feet elevation, features light traffic, minimal wind, and has been acknowledged by local law enforcement for use.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF THE PACIFIC
articles.summary: This document introduces the Astronomical Society of the Pacific and notes its association with the Lawrence Hall of Science. The content provided is minimal, essentially just listing the names of these two entities.

articles.title: Lawrence Hall of Science, Berkeley, California
articles.summary: This document introduces the Lawrence Hall of Science, an educational institution located in Berkeley, California. It serves as a brief mention or heading for content related to this specific science center.

articles.title: CALL FOR PAPERS and REGISTRATION
articles.summary: This document is a call for papers and registration announcement for an astronomy conference featuring professional speakers like Loren Acton, Clark Chapman, and Andrew Fraknoi, alongside papers from amateur astronomers. The event will include a swap meet, astrophotography competition, commercial and club exhibits, a banquet, and a star party, with a pre-conference star party at Fremont Peak State Park. Registration details, deadlines, and contact information for paper submissions and general inquiries are provided.

articles.title: AANC 1987 CONFERENCE REGISTRATION FORM
articles.summary: This document is a registration form for the 1987 AANC (Astronomical Association of Northern California) Conference. It allows attendees to register for the conference, select dinner options, request tickets for a planetarium show, and indicate participation in an astrophotography contest and a star party at Fremont Peak.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, featuring guest speakers on diverse astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share their interests. These meetings cultivate a friendly atmosphere for various pursuits like astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. The article also provides detailed directions, location, and start times for these gatherings.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The 'INDOOR STAR PARTIES' are monthly Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. These events often feature telescopes set up in the parking lot or astrophotography slideshows indoors. Additionally, the SJAA conducts Board Meetings and an Introductory Astronomy workshop during these times.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays closest to the New Moon. These field expeditions take place at various designated locations, ranging from sites near San Jose to distant places like Yosemite National Park, with directions provided in the EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly favored location for Bay Area amateur astronomers, hosting serious deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, often attracting 50-100 telescopes. It is also home to the Fremont Peak Observatory Association's 30" Coudé telescope, which is open to the public on selected weekends. The article provides detailed directions to the park and information about the San Jose Astronomical Association, including its publication, 'EPHEMERIS', and contact details for its officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines various membership types, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T', and 'Junior (Under 18)', along with their respective fees. The form requests applicant's name, address, and telephone number, and provides instructions for submission via mail or in-person at an SJAA meeting.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document features an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about individuals' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise. It also includes mailing information for the SJAA EPHEMERIS, a non-profit organization, and is labeled as 'NEWS MATERIAL' with a 'TIME VALUE — DATED' stamp.
